member.summary: ToLower implements the one-to-one Unicode lowercase mapping as descriped in ftp://ftp.unicode.org/Public/UNIDATA/UnicodeData.txt. The VB spec states that these mappings are used for case-insensitive comparison

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CodeGen.ILBuilder.allocatedILMarkers
member.summary:
In some cases we have to get a final IL offset during emit phase, for example for proper emitting sequence points. The problem is that before the builder is realized we don't know the actual IL offset, but only {block/offset-in-the-block} pair.
Thus, whenever we need to mark some IL position we allocate a new marker id, store it in allocatedILMarkers and reference this IL marker in the entity requiring the IL offset.
IL markers will be 'materialized' when the builder is realized; the resulting offsets will be put into allocatedILMarkers array. Note that only markers from reachable blocks are materialized, the rest will have offset -1.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CodeGen.ILBuilder.InstructionsEmitted
member.summary:
IL opcodes emitted by this builder. This includes branch instructions that end blocks except if they are fall-through NOPs.
This count allows compilers to see if emitting a particular statement/expression actually produced any instructions.
Example: a label will not result in any code so when emitting debugging information an extra NOP may be needed if we want to decorate the label with sequence point.

M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CodeGen.ILBuilder.DefineSequencePoint(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxTree,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Text.TextSpan)
member.summary: Define a sequence point with the given syntax tree and span within it.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CodeGen.ILBuilder.DefineHiddenSequencePoint
member.summary:
Defines a hidden sequence point. The effect of this is that debugger will not associate following code with any source (until it sees a lexically following sequence point).
This is used for synthetic code that is reachable through labels.
If such code is not separated from previous sequence point by the means of a hidden sequence point It looks as a part of the statement that previous sequence point specifies. As a result, when user steps through the code and goes through a jump to such label, it will appear as if the jump landed at the beginning of the previous statement.
NOTE: Also inserted as the first statement of a method that would not otherwise have a leading sequence point so that step-into will find the method body.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CodeGen.ILBuilder.DefineInitialHiddenSequencePoint
member.summary: Define a hidden sequence point at the first statement of the method so that step-into will find the method body.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CodeGen.ILBuilder.SetInitialDebugDocument(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxTree)
member.summary: This is called when starting emitting a method for which there is some source. It is done in case the first sequence point is a hidden point. Even though hidden points do not have syntax, they need to associate with some document.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CodeGen.ILBuilder.MarkFilterConditionEnd

member.summary: See Microsoft.Cci.ILocalScopeProvider.GetIteratorScopes. This is called within an iterator scope to identify that a field named "<Xyzzy>5__i" is used to represent a local variable named Xyzzy. The "i" is an integer, which is passed to this method as the index parameter.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CodeGen.LocalSlotManager
member.summary:
At this level there are two kinds of local variables:
Locals - have identities by which consuming code refers to them. Typical use is a local variable or a compiler generated temp that can be accessed in multiple operations. Any object can be used as identity. Reference equality is used.
Temps - do not have identity. They are borrowed and returned to the free list. Typical use is a scratch temporary or spilling storage.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CodeGen.PermissionSetAttributeWithFileReference
member.summary: This class represents the PermissionSetAttribute specified in source which needs fixup during codegen.
member.remarks: PermissionSetAttribute needs fixup when it contains an assignment to the 'File' property as a single named attribute argument. Fixup performed is ported from SecurityAttributes::FixUpPermissionSetAttribute at ndp\clr\src\vm\securityattributes.cpp. It involves following steps: 1) Verifying that the specified file name resolves to a valid path: This is done during binding. 2) Reading the contents of the file into a byte array. 3) Convert each byte in the file content into two bytes containing hexa-decimal characters (see method ). 4) Replacing the 'File = fileName' named argument with 'Hex = hexFileContent' argument, where hexFileContent is the converted output from step 3) above.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CodeGen.ReferenceDependencyWalker
member.summary:
Some features of the compiler (such as anonymous types, pay-as-you-go, NoPIA, ...) rely on all referenced symbols to go through translate mechanism. Because by default symbol translator does not translate some of indirectly referenced symbols, such as type argument, we have to force translation here
This class provides unified implementation for this functionality.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CodeGen.SequencePointList
member.summary:
Maintains a list of sequence points in a space efficient way. Most of the time sequence points occur in the same syntax tree, so optimize for that case. Store a sequence point as an offset, and position in a syntax tree, then translate to CCI format only on demand.
Use a ArrayBuilder{RawSequencePoint} to create.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CodeGen.StringTokenMap
member.summary: Handles storage of strings referenced via tokens in metadata. When items are stored they are uniquely "associated" with fake token, which is basically a sequential number. IL gen will use these fake tokens during codegen and later, when actual token values are known the method bodies will be patched. To support thse two scenarios we need two maps - Item-->uint, and uint-->Item. (the second is really just a list).

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Collections.CachingDictionary`2
member.summary:
The CachingLookup class provides a convenient representation of an ILookup that is based upon a potentially slow lookup, and caches lookup results so that subsequent lookups are fast. Internally a ConcurrentDictionary is used to cache lookup results. The client provides two delegates to perform lookups: One that maps a key to a IEnumerable of values, and one that provides all keys.
The client must provide an IEqualityComparer used for comparing keys. Failed lookups are cached, but that has the disadvantage that every different failed lookup will consume a small amount of extra memory. However, that memory can be reclaimed by forcing a full population of the cache.
Thread safe.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Collections.CachingDictionary`2.#ctor(System.Func{`0,System.Collections.Immutable.ImmutableArray{`1}},System.Func{System.Collections.Generic.IEqualityComparer{`0},System.Collections.Generic.HashSet{`0}},System.Collections.Generic.IEqualityComparer{`0})
member.summary: Create a CachingLookup.
member.param: A function that takes a key, and returns an IEnumerable of values that correspond to that key. If no values correspond, the function may either return null or an empty IEnumerable.
A function that returns an IEnumerable of all keys that have associated values.
A IEqualityComparer used to compare keys.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Collections.PooledStringBuilder
T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Collections.SmallConcurrentSetOfInts
member.summary: A set of ints that is small, thread-safe and lock free. Several assumptions have been made that allow it to be small and fast: 1. Deletes never happen. 2. The size is small. In dogfooding experiements, 89% had 4 or fewer elements and 98% had 8 or fewer elements. The largest size was 17. 3. As a result of assumption 2, linear look-up is good enough. 4. One value, in this case int.MinValue, is used as a sentinel and may never appear in the set.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Emit.EmitBaseline
member.summary: Represents a module from a previous compilation. Used in Edit and Continue to emit the differences in a subsequent compilation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Emit.EmitBaseline.CreateInitialBaseline(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.ModuleMetadata,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Emit.LocalVariableNameProvider)
member.summary: Creates an from the metadata of the module before editing and from a function that maps from a method to an array of local names.
member.param: The metadata of the module before editing.
A function that returns the array of local names given a method index from the module metadata.
member.returns: An for the module.
member.remarks:
Only the initial baseline is created using this method; subsequent baselines are created automatically when emitting the differences in subsequent compilations.
When an active method (one for which a frame is allocated on a stack) is updated the values of its local variables need to be preserved. The mapping of local variable names to their slots in the frame is not included in the metadata and thus needs to be provided by .
The is only needed for the initial generation. The mapping for the subsequent generations is carried over through . The compiler assigns slots to named local variables (including named temporary variables) it the order in which they appear in the source code. This property allows the compiler to reconstruct the local variable mapping for the initial generation. A subsequent generation may add a new variable in between two variables of the previous generation. Since the slots of the previous generation variables need to be preserved the only option is to add these new variables to the end. The slot ordering thus no longer matches the syntax ordering. It is therefore necessary to pass to the next generation (rather than e.g. create new s from scratch based on metadata produced by subsequent compilations).

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.UnionCollection`1
member.summary:
Implements a readonly collection over a set of existing collections. This can be used to prevent having to copy items from one collection over to another (thus bloating space).
Note: this is a *collection*, not a *set*. There is no removal of duplicated elements. This allows us to be able to efficiently do operations like CopyTo, Count, etc. in O(c) time instead of O(n) (where 'c' is the number of collections and 'n' is the number of elements). If you have a few collections with many elements in them, then this is an appropriate collection for you.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason
member.summary: Indicates the reasons why a candidate (or set of candidate) symbols were not considered correct in SemanticInfo. Higher values take precedence over lower values, so if, for example, there a symbol with a given name that was inaccessible, and other with the wrong arity, only the inaccessible one would be reported in the SemanticInfo.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.None
member.summary: No CandidateSymbols.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.NotATypeOrNamespace
member.summary: Only a type or namespace was valid in the given location, but the candidate symbols was of the wrong kind.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.NotAnEvent
member.summary: Only an event was valid in the given location, but the candidate symbols was of the wrong kind.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.NotAWithEventsMember
member.summary: The candidate symbol must be a WithEvents member, but it was not.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.NotAnAttributeType
member.summary: Only an attribute type was valid in the given location, but the candidate symbol was of the wrong kind.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.WrongArity
member.summary: The candidate symbol takes a different number of type parameters that was required.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.NotCreatable
member.summary: The candidate symbol existed, but was not allowed to be created in a new expression. For example, interfaces, static classes, and unconstrained type parameters.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.NotReferencable
member.summary: The candidate symbol existed, but was not allowed to be referenced. For example, the "get_XXX" method used to implement a property named "XXX" may not be directly referenced. Similarly, the type "System.Void" can not be directly referenced. Also occurs if "this" is used in a context (static method or field initializer) where "this" is not available.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.Inaccessible
member.summary: The candidate symbol had an accessibility modifier (private, protected, ...) that made it inaccessible.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.NotAValue
member.summary: The candidate symbol was in a place where a value was required, but was not a value (e.g., was a type or namespace).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.NotAVariable
member.summary: The candidate symbol was in a place where a variable (or sometimes, a property) was required, but was not allowed there because it isn't a symbol that can be assigned to. For example, the left hand side of an assignment, or a ref or out parameter.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.NotInvocable
member.summary: The candidate symbol was used in a way that an invocable member (method, or variable of delegate type) was required, but the candidate symbol was not invocable.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.StaticInstanceMismatch
member.summary: The candidate symbol must be an instance variable, but was used as static, or the reverse.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.OverloadResolutionFailure
member.summary: Overload resolution did not choose a method. The candidate symbols are the methods there were considered during overload resolution (which may or may not be applicable methods).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.LateBound
member.summary: Method could not be selected statically. The candidate symbols are the methods there were considered during overload resolution (which may or may not be applicable methods).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CandidateReason.Ambiguous
member.summary: Multiple ambiguous symbols were available with the same name. This can occur if "using" statements bring multiple namespaces into scope, and the same type is available in multiple. This can also occur if multiple properties of the same name are available in a multiple interface inheritance situation.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonMemberResolutionKind
member.summary: Indicates why the compiler accepted or rejected the member during overload resolution.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonMemberResolutionKind.Applicable
member.summary: The candidate member was accepted.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonMemberResolutionKind.UseSiteError
member.summary: The candidate member was rejected because it is not supported by the language or cannot be used given the current set of assembly references.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonMemberResolutionKind.TypeInferenceFailed
member.summary: The candidate member was rejected because type inference failed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonMemberResolutionKind.Worse
member.summary: The candidate member was rejected because it was considered worse that another member.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonMemberResolutionResult`1
member.summary: Represents the results of overload resolution for a single member.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonMemberResolutionResult`1.Member
member.summary: The member considered during overload resolution.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonMemberResolutionResult`1.Resolution
member.summary: Indicates why the compiler accepted or rejected the member during overload resolution.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonMemberResolutionResult`1.IsValid
member.summary: Returns true if the compiler accepted this member as the sole correct result of overload resolution.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonOverloadResolutionResult`1
member.summary: Summarizes the results of an overload resolution analysis, as described in section 7.5 of the language specification. Describes whether overload resolution succeeded, and which method was selected if overload resolution succeeded, as well as detailed information about each method that was considered.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonOverloadResolutionResult`1.Succeeded
member.summary: True if overload resolution successfully selected a single best method.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonOverloadResolutionResult`1.ValidResult
member.summary: If overload resolution successfully selected a single best method, returns information about that method. Otherwise returns null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonOverloadResolutionResult`1.BestResult
member.summary: If there was a method that overload resolution considered better than all others, returns information about that method. A method may be returned even if that method was not considered a successful overload resolution, as long as it was better that any other potential method considered.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonOverloadResolutionResult`1.Results
member.summary: Returns information about each method that was considered during overload resolution, and what the results of overload resolution were for that method.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Compilation
member.summary: The compilation object is an immutable representation of a single invocation of the compiler. Although immutable, a compilation is also on-demand, and will realize and cache data as necessary. A compilation can produce a new compilation from existing compilation with the application of small deltas. In many cases, it is more efficient than creating a new compilation from scratch, as the new compilation can reuse information from the old compilation.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Compilation.IsCaseSensitive
member.summary: Returns true if this is a case sensitive compilation, false otherwise. Case sensitivity affects compilation features such as name lookup as well as choosing what names to emit when there are multiple different choices (for example between a virtual method and an override).

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Compilation.Emit(System.IO.Stream,System.String,System.String,System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.ResourceDescription},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Emit the IL for the compiled source code into the specified stream.
member.param: Stream to which the compilation will be written.

Name of the compilation: file name and extension. Null to use the compilation name. CAUTION: If this is set to a (non-null) value other than the existing compilation output name, then internals-visible-to and assembly references may not work as expected. In particular, things that were visible at bind time, based on the name of the compilation, may not be visible at runtime and vice-versa.
The name of the PDB file embedded in the PE image. If not specified, the file name of the source module with an extension changed to "pdb" is used. Ignored unless is non-null.
Stream to which the compilation's debug info will be written. Null to forego PDB generation.
Stream to which the compilation's XML documentation will be written. Null to forego XML generation.
To cancel the emit process.
Stream from which the compilation's Win32 resources will be read (in RES format). Null to indicate that there are none. The RES format begins with a null resource entry.
List of the compilation's managed resources. Null to indicate that there are none.

member.summary: Emits the IL for the symbol declarations into the specified stream. Useful for emitting information for cross-language modeling of code. This emits what it can even if there are errors.

Name of the compilation: file name and extension. Null to use the existing output name. CAUTION: If this is set to a (non-null) value other than the existing compilation output name, then internals-visible-to and assembly references may not work as expected. In particular, things that were visible at bind time, based on the name of the compilation, may not be visible at runtime and vice-versa.
Stream from which the compilation's Win32 resources will be read (in RES format). Null to indicate that there are none. The RES format begins with a null resource entry.
List of the compilation's managed resources. Null to indicate that there are none.
Options controlling the emitted metadata.
To cancel the emit process.

member.summary: Emit the differences between the compilation and the previous generation for Edit and Continue. The differences are expressed as added and changed symbols, and are emitted as metadata, IL, and PDB deltas. A representation of the current compilation is returned as an EmitBaseline for use in a subsequent Edit and Continue.
This overload is only intended to be directly called by tests that want to pass . The map is used for storing a list of methods and their associated IL.
member.returns: True if emit succeeded.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Compilation.retargetingAssemblySymbols
member.summary:
The list of RetargetingAssemblySymbol objects created for this Compilation. RetargetingAssemblySymbols are created when some other compilation references this one, but the other references provided are incompatible with it. For example, compilation C1 references v1 of Lib.dll and compilation C2 references C1 and v2 of Lib.dll. In this case, in context of C2, all types from v1 of Lib.dll leaking through C1 (through method signatures, etc.) must be retargeted to the types from v2 of Lib.dll. This is what RetargetingAssemblySymbol is responsible for. In the example above, modules in C2 do not reference C1.AssemblySymbol, but reference a special RetargetingAssemblySymbol created for C1 by ReferenceManager.
WeakReference is used to allow RetargetingAssemblySymbol to be collected when they become unused.
Guarded by .

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Compilation.CacheRetargetingAssemblySymbolNoLock(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.IAssemblySymbol)
member.summary: Adds given retargeting assembly for this compilation into the cache. must be locked while calling this method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Compilation.AddRetargetingAssemblySymbolsNoLock``1(System.Collections.Generic.List{``0})
member.summary: Adds cached retargeting symbols into the given list. must be locked while calling this method.

The name usually (but not necessarily) includes an extension, e.g. "MyModule.dll".
If is null the actual name written to metadata is derived from the name of the compilation () by appending a default extension for .

member.summary: The full name of a type that declares static Main method. Must be a valid non-generic namespace-qualified name. Null if any static Main method is a candidate for an entry point.

member.summary: Options that can be used to control metadata-only emit.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.MetadataOnlyEmitOptions.TolerateErrors
member.summary: Tolerate errors, producing a PE stream and a success result even in the presence of (some) errors. This parameter is currently ignored.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.MetadataOnlyEmitOptions.IncludePrivateMembers
member.summary: If not set, exclude (some) private members from the generated assembly when they do not affect the language semantics of the resulting assembly. This option is currently ignored.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.OptimizationLevel
member.summary: Determines the level of optimization of the generated code.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.OptimizationLevel.Debug
member.summary: Disables all optimizations and instruments the generated code to improve debugging experience.
member.remarks:
The compiler prefers debuggability over performance. Do not use for code running in a production environment.
JIT optimizations are disabled via assembly level attribute ().
Edit and Continue is enabled.
Slots for local variables are not reused, lifetime of local variables is extended to make the values available during debugging.
Corresponds to command line argument /optimize-.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.OptimizationLevel.Release
member.summary: Enables all optimizations, debugging experience might be degraded.
member.remarks:
The compiler prefers performance over debuggability. Use for code running in a production environment.
JIT optimizations are enabled via assembly level attribute ().
Edit and Continue is disabled.
Sequence points may be optimized away. As a result it might not be possible to place or hit a breakpoint.
User-defined locals migth be optimized away. They might not be available while debugging.
Corresponds to command line argument /optimize+.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SemanticModel
member.summary: Allows asking semantic questions about a tree of syntax nodes in a Compilation. Typically, an instance is obtained by a call to GetBinding on a Compilation or Compilation.

remarks.para: An instance of SemanticModel caches local symbols and semantic information. Thus, it is much more efficient to use a single instance of SemanticModel when asking multiple questions about a syntax tree, because information from the first question may be reused. This also means that holding onto an instance of SemanticModel for a long time may keep a significant amount of memory from being garbage collected.

When an answer is a named symbol that is reachable by traversing from the root of the symbol table, (that is, from an AssemblySymbol of the Compilation), that symbol will be returned (i.e. the returned value will be reference-equal to one reachable from the root of the symbol table). Symbols representing entities without names (e.g. array-of-int) may or may not exhibit reference equality. However, some named symbols (such as local variables) are not reachable from the root. These symbols are visible as answers to semantic questions. When the same SemanticModel object is used, the answers exhibit reference-equality.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SemanticModel.GetSpeculativeSymbolInfo(System.Int32,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxNode,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SpeculativeBindingOption)
member.summary: Binds the node in the context of the specified location and get semantic information such as type, symbols and diagnostics. This method is used to get semantic information about an expression that did not actually appear in the source code.
member.param: A character position used to identify a declaration scope and accessibility. This character position must be within the FullSpan of the Root syntax node in this SemanticModel.
A syntax node that represents a parsed expression. This syntax node need not and typically does not appear in the source code referred to SemanticModel instance.

Indicates whether to binding the expression as a full expressions, or as a type or namespace. If SpeculativeBindingOption.BindAsTypeOrNamespace is supplied, then expression should derive from TypeSyntax.
member.returns: The semantic information for the topmost node of the expression.
member.remarks: The passed in expression is interpreted as a stand-alone expression, as if it appeared by itself somewhere within the scope that encloses "position".

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SemanticModel.GetSyntaxDiagnostics(System.Nullable{Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Text.TextSpan},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get all of the syntax errors within the syntax tree associated with this object. Does not get errors involving declarations or compiling method bodies or initializers.
member.param: Optional span within the syntax tree for which to get diagnostics. If no argument is specified, then diagnostics for the entire tree are returned.
A cancellation token that can be used to cancel the process of obtaining the diagnostics.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SemanticModel.GetDeclarationDiagnostics(System.Nullable{Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Text.TextSpan},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get all of the declaration errors within the syntax tree associated with this object. Does not get errors involving incorrect syntax, compiling method bodies or initializers.
member.param: Optional span within the syntax tree for which to get diagnostics. If no argument is specified, then diagnostics for the entire tree are returned.
A cancellation token that can be used to cancel the process of obtaining the diagnostics.
member.remarks: The declaration errors for a syntax tree are cached. The first time this method is called, all declarations are analyzed for diagnostics. Calling this a second time will return the cached diagnostics.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SemanticModel.GetMethodBodyDiagnostics(System.Nullable{Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Text.TextSpan},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get all of the method body and initializer errors within the syntax tree associated with this object. Does not get errors involving incorrect syntax or declarations.
member.param: Optional span within the syntax tree for which to get diagnostics. If no argument is specified, then diagnostics for the entire tree are returned.
A cancellation token that can be used to cancel the process of obtaining the diagnostics.
member.remarks: The method body errors for a syntax tree are not cached. The first time this method is called, all method bodies are analyzed for diagnostics. Calling this a second time will repeat this work.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SemanticModel.GetDiagnostics(System.Nullable{Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Text.TextSpan},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Get all the errors within the syntax tree associated with this object. Includes errors involving compiling method bodies or initializers, in addition to the errors returned by GetDeclarationDiagnostics.
member.param: Optional span within the syntax tree for which to get diagnostics. If no argument is specified, then diagnostics for the entire tree are returned.
A cancellation token that can be used to cancel the process of obtaining the diagnostics.
member.remarks: Because this method must semantically bind all method bodies and initializers to check for diagnostics, it may take a significant amount of time. Unlike GetDeclarationDiagnostics, diagnostics for method bodies and initializers are not cached, any semantic information used to obtain the diagnostics is discarded.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SemanticModel.LookupSymbols(System.Int32,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.INamespaceOrTypeSymbol,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the available named symbols in the context of the specified location and optional container. Only symbols that are accessible and visible from the given location are returned.
member.param: The character position for determining the enclosing declaration scope and accessibility.
The container to search for symbols within. If null then the enclosing declaration scope around position is used.
The name of the symbol to find. If null is specified then symbols with any names are returned.
Consider (reduced) extension methods.
member.returns: A list of symbols that were found. If no symbols were found, an empty list is returned.
member.remarks:
The "position" is used to determine what variables are visible and accessible. Even if "container" is specified, the "position" location is significant for determining which members of "containing" are accessible.
Labels are not considered (see ).
Non-reduced extension methods are considered regardless of the value of .

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SemanticModel.LookupStaticMembers(System.Int32,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.INamespaceOrTypeSymbol,System.String)
member.summary:
Gets the available named static member symbols in the context of the specified location and optional container. Only members that are accessible and visible from the given location are returned.
Non-reduced extension methods are considered, since they are static methods.
member.param: The character position for determining the enclosing declaration scope and accessibility.
The container to search for symbols within. If null then the enclosing declaration scope around position is used.
The name of the symbol to find. If null is specified then symbols with any names are returned.
member.returns: A list of symbols that were found. If no symbols were found, an empty list is returned.
member.remarks:
The "position" is used to determine what variables are visible and accessible. Even if "container" is specified, the "position" location is significant for determining which members of "containing" are accessible.
Essentially the same as filtering instance members out of the results of an analogous call.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SemanticModel.ResolveOverloads``1(System.Int32,System.Collections.Immutable.ImmutableArray{``0},System.Collections.Immutable.ImmutableArray{Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.ITypeSymbol},System.Collections.Immutable.ImmutableArray{Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SyntaxNode})
member.summary: Resolves the set of provided arguments against set of provided members to determine the appropriate overload. The arguments are bound as if they were at 'position' within this semantic model. An CommonOverloadResolutionResult is returned that gives the result of the compiler's overload resolution analysis.
member.param: A character position used to identify a declaration scope and accessibility. This character position must be within the FullSpan of the Root syntax node in this SemanticModel. This position is used when binding the arguments.
The set of members to resolve overloads among.
The list of arguments, in order, to use when resolving the overloads. The arguments are interpreted as if they occurred within the declaration scope that encloses "position".
If present, the type argument provided. If not provided, type inference is done.
member.remarks: This can be used to resolve constructors, properties as well as methods.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolInfo.Symbol
member.summary: The symbol that was referred to by the syntax node, if any. Returns null if the given expression did not bind successfully to a single symbol. member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolInfo.CandidateSymbols
member.summary: If the expression did not successfully resolve to a symbol, but there were one or more symbols that may have been considered but discarded, this property returns those symbols. The reason that the symbols did not successfully resolve to a symbol are available in the CandidateReason property. For example, if the symbol was inaccessible, ambiguous, or used in the wrong context.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolInfo.CandidateReason
member.summary: If the expression did not successfully resolve to a symbol, but there were one or more symbols that may have been considered but discarded, this property describes why those symbol or symbols were not considered suitable.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.TypeInfo.ConvertedType

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.DiagnosticBag
member.summary:
Represents a mutable bag of diagnostics. You can add diagnostics to the bag, and also get all the diagnostics out of the bag (the bag implements IEnumerable<Diagnostics>. Once added, diagnostics cannot be removed, and no ordering is guaranteed.
It is ok to Add diagnostics to the same bag concurrently on multiple threads. It is NOT ok to Add concurrently with Clear or Free operations.
member.remarks: The bag is optimized to be efficient when containing zero errors.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.DiagnosticBag.IsEmptyWithoutResolution
member.summary: Return true if the bag is completely empty - not even containing void diagnostics.
member.remarks: This exists for short-circuiting purposes. Use to get a resolved Tuple(Of NamedTypeSymbol, ImmutableArray(Of Diagnostic)) (i.e. empty after eliminating void diagnostics).

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.DiagnosticBag.HasAnyErrors
member.summary: Returns true if the bag has any diagnostics with Severity=Error. Does not consider warnings or informationals.
member.remarks:
Resolves any lazy diagnostics in the bag.
Generally, this should only be called by the creator (modulo pooling) of the bag (i.e. don't use bags to communicate - if you need more info, pass more info).

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.DiagnosticBag.Add(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Diagnostic)
member.summary: Add a diagnostic to the bag.

member.summary: Add multiple diagnostics to the bag.

member.summary: Add multiple diagnostics to the bag.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.DiagnosticBag.AddRange(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.DiagnosticBag)
member.summary: Add another DiagnosticBag to the bag.

member.summary: Add another DiagnosticBag to the bag and free the argument.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.DiagnosticBag.ToReadOnlyAndFree``1
member.summary: Seal the bag so no further errors can be added, while clearing it and returning the old set of errors. Return the bag to the pool.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.DiagnosticBag.AsEnumerable
member.remarks: Generally, this should only be called by the creator (modulo pooling) of the bag (i.e. don't use bags to communicate - if you need more info, pass more info).

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.DiagnosticBag.AsEnumerableFiltered
member.remarks: Using an iterator to avoid copying the list. If perf is a problem, create an explicit enumerator type.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.DiagnosticBag.Bag
member.summary: Get the underlying concurrent storage, creating it on demand if needed. NOTE: Concurrent Adding to the bag is supported, but concurrent Clearing is not. If one thread adds to the bug while another clears it, the scenario is broken and we cannot do anything about it here.

members.member: NOTE: Concurrent Adding to the bag is supported, but concurrent Clearing is not. If one thread adds to the bug while another clears it, the scenario is broken and we cannot do anything about it here.

member.summary: Create a DiagnosticDescriptor, which provides description about a .
member.param: A unique identifier for the diagnostic. For example, code analysis diagnostic ID "CA1001".
A short localizable title describing the diagnostic. For example, for CA1001: "Types that own disposable fields should be disposable".

A localizable format message string, which can be passed as the first argument to when creating the diagnostic message with this descriptor. For example, for CA1001: "Implement IDisposable on '{0}' because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: '{1}'."
The category of the diagnostic (like Design, Naming etc.). For example, for CA1001: "Microsoft.Design".
Default severity of the diagnostic.
True if the diagnostic is enabled by default.
An optional longer localizable description of the diagnostic.
An optional hyperlink that provides a more detailed description regarding the diagnostic.
Optional custom tags for the diagnostic. See for some well known tags.

member.summary: Fetches a documentation comment for the given member ID.
member.param: The documentation member ID of the item to fetch.

The preferred culture to receive a comment in. Null if there is no preference. This is a preference only, and providers may choose to provide results from another culture if the preferred culture was unavailable.
A cancellation token for the search.
member.returns: A DocumentationComment.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.DocumentationProvider.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: DocumentationProviders are compared when determining whether an AssemblySymbol can be reused. Hence, if multiple instances can represent the same documentation, it is imperative that Equals (and GetHashCode) be overridden to capture this fact. Otherwise, it is possible to end up with multiple AssemblySymbols for the same assembly, which plays havoc with the type hierarchy.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.DocumentationProvider.GetHashCode
member.summary: DocumentationProviders are compared when determining whether an AssemblySymbol can be reused. Hence, if multiple instances can represent the same documentation, it is imperative that GetHashCode (and Equals) be overridden to capture this fact. Otherwise, it is possible to end up with multiple AssemblySymbols for the same assembly, which plays havoc with the type hierarchy.

member.summary: Returns a logger that logs 'start' and 'end' messages for a supplied event along with a number and a string. The combination of the 'start' and the 'end' message is referred to as a 'block' and each block has a unique 'blockId'.
member.param: A number that uniquely identifies the event being logged.
A number that is logged as part of the 'end' message.
A string that is logged as part of the 'start' message.

A number that uniquely identifies the 'start' and 'end' messages for a particular occurrence of the event in the log. In other words, each occurrence of the event will result in 'start' and 'end' messages that share the same unique blockId in the log.
A cancellation token - If the operation was cancelled then a 'cancelled' message is logged in place of a 'end' meessage for the event.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.RuntimeMembers.MemberDescriptor
member.summary: Structure that describes a member of a type.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.RuntimeMembers.MemberDescriptor.DeclaringTypeId
member.summary:
Id/token of containing type, usually value from some enum. For example from SpecialType enum. I am not using SpecialType as the type for this field because VB runtime types are not part of SpecialType.
So, the implication is that any type ids we use outside of the SpecialType (either for the VB runtime classes, or types like System.Task etc.) will need to use IDs that are all mutually disjoint.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.RuntimeMembers.MemberDescriptor.Signature
member.summary: Signature of the field or method, similar to metadata signature, but with the following exceptions: 1) Truncated on the left, for methods starts at [ParamCount], for fields at [Type] 2) Type tokens are not compressed 3) BOOLEAN | CHAR | I1 | U1 | I2 | U2 | I4 | U4 | I8 | U8 | R4 | R8 | I | U | Void types are encoded by using VALUETYPE+typeId notation. 4) array bounds are not included. 5) modifiers are not included. 6) (CLASS | VALUETYPE) are omitted after GENERICINST

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.MetadataHelpers.SerializedTypeDecoder
member.summary: Decodes a serialized type name in its canonical form. The canonical name is its full type name, followed optionally by the assembly where it is defined, its version, culture and public key token. If the assembly name is omitted, the type name is in the current assembly otherwise it is in the referenced assembly. The full type name is the fully qualified metadata type name.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.MetadataHelpers.SerializedTypeDecoder.DecodeTypeName(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Decodes a type name. A type name is a string which is terminated by the end of the string or one of the delimiters '+', ',', '[', ']'. '+' separates nested classes. '[' and ']' enclosed generic type arguments. ',' separates types.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.MetadataHelpers.SerializedTypeDecoder.DecodeGenericName(System.Int32)
member.summary: Decodes a generic name. This is a type name followed optionally by a type parameter count

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.MetadataHelpers.SplitQualifiedNameSystem
member.summary: An ImmutableArray representing the single string "System"
Calculates information about types and namespaces immediately contained within a namespace.
member.param: Length of the fully-qualified name of this namespace.

The sequence of groups of TypeDef row ids for types contained within the namespace, recursively including those from nested namespaces. The row ids must be grouped by the fully-qualified namespace name in case-sensitive manner. Key of each IGrouping is a fully-qualified namespace name, which starts with the name of this namespace. There could be multiple groups for each fully-qualified namespace name.
The groups must be sorted by the keys in a manner consistent with comparer passed in as nameComparer. Therefore, all types immediately contained within THIS namespace, if any, must be in several IGrouping at the very beginning of the sequence.
Equality comparer to compare namespace names.
Output parameter, never null: A sequence of groups of TypeDef row ids for types immediately contained within this namespace.

Output parameter, never null: A sequence with information about namespaces immediately contained within this namespace. For each pair: Key - contains simple name of a child namespace. Value contains a sequence similar to the one passed to this function, but calculated for the child namespace.

member.param: Parent namespace name length plus the dot.
Fully qualified namespace name.
member.returns: Simple name of a top level child namespace, the left-most name following parent namespace name in the fully qualified name.

member.summary: Determines whether given string can be used as a non-empty metadata identifier (a NUL-terminated UTF8 string).

member.summary: True if the string doesn't contain incomplete surrogates.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.MetadataHelpers.IsValidMetadataFileName(System.String)
member.summary:
Checks that the specified name is a valid metadata String and a file name. The specification isn't entirely consistent and complete but it mentiones:
22.19.2: "Name shall index a non-empty string in the String heap. It shall be in the format {filename}.{extension} (e.g., 'foo.dll', but not 'c:\utils\foo.dll')." 22.30.2: "The format of Name is {file name}.{file extension} with no path or drive letter; on POSIX-compliant systems Name contains no colon, no forward-slash, no backslash." As Microsoft specific constraint.
A reasonable restriction seems to be a valid UTF8 non-empty string that doesn't contain '\0', '\', '/', ':' characters.

member.returns: true if the combination of and equals the fully-qualified name given by

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.PEModule.GetReferencedManagedModulesOrThrow
member.summary: Returns names of referenced modules.

members.member:
The function groups types defined in the module by their fully-qualified namespace name. The case-sensitivity of the grouping depends upon the provided StringComparer.
The sequence is sorted by name by using provided comparer. Therefore, if there are multiple groups for a namespace name (e.g. because they differ in case), the groups are going to be adjacent to each other.
Empty string is used as namespace name for types in the Global namespace. Therefore, all types in the Global namespace, if any, should be in the first group (assuming a reasonable StringComparer).
Comparer to sort the groups.
A sorted list of TypeDef row ids, grouped by fully-qualified namespace name. An exception from metadata reader.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.PEModule.GetTypeNamespaceNamesOrThrow(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.ArrayBuilder{System.Reflection.Metadata.TypeHandle}})
member.summary: Groups together the RowIds of types in a given namespaces. The types considered are those defined in this module.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.PEModule.GetForwardedTypeNamespaceNamesOrThrow(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.ArrayBuilder{System.Reflection.Metadata.TypeHandle}})
member.summary:
Supplements the namespace-to-RowIDs map with the namespaces of forwarded types. These types will not have associated row IDs (represented as null, for efficiency). These namespaces are important because we want lookups of missing forwarded types to succeed far enough that we can actually find the type forwarder and provide information about the target assembly.
For example, consider the following forwarded type:
.class extern forwarder Namespace.Type {}
If this type is referenced in source as "Namespace.Type", then dev10 reports
error CS1070: The type name 'Namespace.Name' could not be found. This type has been forwarded to assembly 'pe2, Version=0.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null'. Consider adding a reference to that assembly.
If we did not include "Namespace" as a child of the global namespace of this module (the forwarding module), then Roslyn would report that the type "Namespace" was not found and say nothing about "Name" (because of the diagnostic already attached to the qualifier).

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.AssemblyMetadata.Copy
member.summary: Creates a shallow copy of contained modules and wraps them into a new instance of .
member.remarks:
The resulting copy shares the metadata images and metadata information read from them with the original. It doesn't own the underlying metadata images and is not responsible for its disposal.
This is used, for example, when a metadata cache needs to return the cached metadata to its users while keeping the ownership of the cached metadata object.

The listed exceptions are caught and converted to compilation diagnostics. Any other exception is considered an unexpected error in the implementation and is not caught.
objects may cache information decoded from the PE image. Reusing instances accross metadata references will result in better performance.
The calling doesn't take ownership of the objects returned by this method. The implementation needs to retrieve the object from a provider that manages their lifetime (such as metadata cache). The object is kept alive by the that called and by all compilations created from it via calls to With- factory methods on , other than overloads. A compilation created using will call to again.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonReferenceManager`2.Bind(System.Collections.Immutable.ImmutableArray{Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonReferenceManager{`0,`1}.AssemblyData},System.Boolean@,System.Int32@)
member.summary:
For the given set of AssemblyData objects, do the following: 1) Resolve references from each assembly against other assemblies in the set. 2) Choose suitable AssemblySymbol instance for each AssemblyData object.
The first element (index==0) of the assemblies array represents the assembly being built. One can think about the rest of the items in assemblies array as assembly references given to the compiler to
build executable for the assembly being built.
member.param: The set of AssemblyData objects describing assemblies, for which this method should resolve references and find suitable AssemblySymbols. This array is not modified by the method.
True if the assembly being compiled is indirectly referenced thru some of its own references.
The definition index of the COR library.
member.returns:
An array of Binding structures describing the result. It has the same amount of items as the input assemblies array, Binding structure for each input AssemblyData object resides at the same position.
Each Binding structure contains the following data:
- Suitable AssemblySymbol instance for the corresponding assembly, null reference if none is available/found. Always null for the first element, which corresponds to the assembly being built.
- Result of resolving assembly references of the corresponding assembly against provided set of assembly definitions. Essentially, this is an array returned by AssemblyData.BindAssemblyReferences method.

members.member:

The target AssemblySymbol instance.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonReferenceManager`2.lazyReferenceDirectiveMap
member.summary: Maps reference string used in #r directive to a resolved metadata reference. If multiple #r's use the same value as a reference the resolved metadata reference is the same as well.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonReferenceManager`2.lazyDirectiveReferences
member.summary: Array of unique bound #r references.
member.remarks: The references are in the order they appear in syntax trees. This order is currently preserved as syntax trees are added or removed, but we might decide to share reference manager between compilations with different order of #r's. It doesn't seem this would be an issue since all #r's within the compilation has the same "priority" with respect to each other.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonReferenceManager`2.lazyDiagnostics
member.summary: Diagnostics produced during reference resolution and binding.
member.remarks: When reporting diagnostics be sure not to include any information that can't be shared among compilations that share the same reference manager (such as full identity of the compilation, simple assembly name is ok).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CommonReferenceManager`2.lazyCorLibraryOpt
member.summary: COR library symbol, or null if the compilation itself is the COR library.
member.remarks: If the compilation being built is the COR library we don't want to store its source assembly symbol here since we wouldn't be able to share the state among subsequent compilations that are derived from it (each of them has its own source assembly symbol).

member.returns: A value that indicates the relative order of the objects being compared. The return value has these meanings: Less than zero: first instance precedes second in the sort order. Zero: first instance occurs in the same position in the sort order as second. Greater than zero: first instance follows second in the sort order.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplay.AbstractSymbolDisplayVisitor`1.AddNonNullConstantValue(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.ITypeSymbol,System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Append a default argument (i.e. the default argument of an optional parameter). Assumed to be non-null.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplay.AbstractSymbolDisplayVisitor`1.IsFlagsEnum(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.ITypeSymbol)
member.summary: Check if the given type is an enum with System.FlagsAttribute.
member.remarks: TODO: Can/should this be done using WellKnownAttributes?

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.FormattedSymbol
member.summary: This class associates a symbol with particular format for display. It can be passed as an argument for an error message in place where symbol display should go, which allows to defer building strings and doing many other things (like loading metadata) associated with that until the error message is actually requested.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayCompilerInternalOptions.None
member.summary: None

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayCompilerInternalOptions.UseMetadataMethodNames
member.summary: ".ctor" instead of "Foo"

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayCompilerInternalOptions.UseArityForGenericTypes
member.summary: "List`1" instead of "List<T>" ("List(of T)" in VB). Overrides GenericsOptions on types.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayCompilerInternalOptions.FlagMissingMetadataTypes
member.summary: Append "[Missing]" to missing Metadata types (for testing).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayCompilerInternalOptions.IncludeScriptType
member.summary: Include the Script type when qualifying type names.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayCompilerInternalOptions.IncludeCustomModifiers
member.summary: Include custom modifiers (e.g. modopt([mscorlib]System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsConst)) on the member (return) type and parameters.
member.remarks: CONSIDER: custom modifiers are part of the public API, so we might want to move this to SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayCompilerInternalOptions.ReverseArrayRankSpecifiers
member.summary: For a type written as "int[][,]" in C#, then a) setting this option will produce "int[,][]", and b) not setting this option will produce "int[][,]".

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayDelegateStyle
member.summary: Specifies how to display delegates (just the name or the name with the signature).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayDelegateStyle.NameOnly
member.summary: Shows only the name of the delegate (e.g. "SomeDelegate").

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayDelegateStyle.NameAndParameters
member.summary: Shows the name and the parameters of the delegate (e.g. "SomeDelegate(int x)").
member.remarks: The format of the parameters will be determined by the other flags passed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayDelegateStyle.NameAndSignature
member.summary: Shows the name and the signature of the delegate (e.g. "void SomeDelegate(int x)").
member.remarks: The format of the signature will be determined by the other flags passed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayExtensionMethodStyle
member.summary: Specifies how how to display extension methods.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayExtensionMethodStyle.StaticMethod
member.summary: Displays the extension method as a static method. For example, Enumerable.ElementAt<TSource>(this IEnumerable<TSource> source, int index).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayExtensionMethodStyle.InstanceMethod
member.summary: Displays the extension method in the form of an instance method. For example, IEnumerable<TSource>.ElementAt<TSource>(int index).

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayExtensions
member.summary: Exposes extension methods for displaying symbol descriptions.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat
member.summary: Describes the formatting rules that should be used when displaying symbols.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.CSharpErrorMessageFormat
member.summary: Formats a symbol description as in a C# compiler error message.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.VisualBasicErrorMessageFormat
member.summary: Formats a symbol description as in a Visual Basic compiler error message.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.FullyQualifiedFormat
member.summary: Formats the names of all types and namespaces in a fully qualified style (including the global alias).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.MinimallyQualifiedFormat
member.summary: Formats a symbol description in a form that suits .

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.TestFormat
member.summary: A verbose format for displaying symbols (useful for testing).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.QualifiedNameOnlyFormat
member.summary: this.QualifiedNameOnly = containingSymbol.QualifiedNameOnly + "." + this.Name

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.QualifiedNameArityFormat
member.summary: this.QualifiedNameArity = containingSymbol.QualifiedNameArity + "." + this.Name + "`" + this.Arity

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.ShortFormat
member.summary: A succinct format for displaying symbols.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.ILVisualizationFormat
member.summary: The format used for displaying symbols when visualizing IL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.ExplicitInterfaceImplementationFormat
member.summary: Used to normalize explicit interface implementation member names. Only expected to be applied to interface types (and their type arguments).

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.GlobalNamespaceStyle
member.summary: Determines how the global namespace is displayed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.TypeQualificationStyle
member.summary: Determines how types are qualified (e.g. Nested vs Containing.Nested vs Namespace.Containing.Nested).

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.GenericsOptions
member.summary: Determines how generics (on types and methods) should be described (i.e. the level of detail).

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.MemberOptions
member.summary: Determines how fields, properties, events, and methods are displayed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.ParameterOptions
member.summary: Determines how parameters (of methods, properties/indexers, and delegates) are displayed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.DelegateStyle
member.summary: Determines how delegates are displayed (e.g. name vs full signature).

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.ExtensionMethodStyle
member.summary: Determines how extension methods are displayed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.PropertyStyle
member.summary: Determines how properties are displayed. For example, "Prop" vs "Prop { get; set; }" in C# or "Prop" vs. "ReadOnly Prop" in Visual Basic.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.LocalOptions
member.summary: Determines how local variables are displayed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.KindOptions
member.summary: Determines which kind keywords should be included when displaying symbols.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.MiscellaneousOptions
member.summary: Determines other characteristics of how symbols are displayed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayFormat.CompilerInternalOptions
member.summary: Flags that can only be set within the compiler.
Constructs a new instance of accepting a variety of optional parameters.
member.param: The settings that determine how the global namespace is displayed.
The settings that determine how types are qualified (e.g. Nested vs Containing.Nested vs Namespace.Containing.Nested).
The settings that determine how generics (on types and methods) should be described (i.e. the level of detail).
The settings that determine how fields, properties, events, and methods are displayed.
The settings that determine how delegates are displayed (e.g. name vs full signature).
The settings that determine how extension methods are displayed.
The settings that determine how parameters (of methods, properties/indexers, and delegates) are displayed.
The settings that determine how properties are displayed. For eaxmple, "Prop" vs "Prop { get; set; }" in C# or "Prop" vs. "ReadOnly Prop" in Visual Basic.
The settings that determine how local variables are displayed.
The settings that determine which kind keywords should be included when displaying symbols.
The settings that determine other characteristics of how symbols are displayed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayGenericsOptions
member.summary: Specifies the options for how generics are displayed in the description of a symbol.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayGenericsOptions.None
member.summary: Omits the type parameter list entirely.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayGenericsOptions.IncludeTypeParameters
member.summary: Includes the type parameters. For example, "Foo<T>" in C# or "Foo(Of T)" in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayGenericsOptions.IncludeTypeConstraints
member.summary: Includes type parameters and constraints. For example, "where T : new()" in C# or "Of T as New" in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayGenericsOptions.IncludeVariance
member.summary: Includes in or out keywords before variant type parameters. For example, "Foo<out T>" in C# or (Foo Of Out T" in Visual Basic.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayGlobalNamespaceStyle
member.summary: Specifies the options for how to display the global namespace in the description of a symbol.
member.remarks: Any of these styles may be overridden by .

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayGlobalNamespaceStyle.Omitted
member.summary: Omits the global namespace, unconditionally.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayGlobalNamespaceStyle.OmittedAsContaining
member.summary: Omits the global namespace if it is being displayed as a containing symbol (i.e. not on its own).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayGlobalNamespaceStyle.Included
member.summary: Include the global namespace, unconditionally.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayKindOptions
member.summary: Specifies which kind keywords should be included when displaying symbols.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayKindOptions.None
member.summary: Omits all kind keywords.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayKindOptions.IncludeNamespaceKeyword
member.summary: Includes the namespace keyword before namespaces. For example, "namespace System", rather than "System".

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayKindOptions.IncludeTypeKeyword
member.summary: Includes the type keyword before types. For example, "class C" in C# or "Structure S" in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayKindOptions.IncludeMemberKeyword
member.summary: Include the member keyword before members (if one exists). For example, "event D E" in C# or "Function MyFun()" in Visual Basic.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayLocalOptions
member.summary: Specifies the options for how locals are displayed in the description of a symbol.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayLocalOptions.None
member.summary: Shows only the name of the local. For example, "x".

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayLocalOptions.IncludeType
member.summary: Shows the type of the local in addition to its name. For example, "int x" in C# or "x As Integer" in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayLocalOptions.IncludeConstantValue
member.summary: Shows the constant value of the local, if there is one, in addition to its name. For example "x = 1".

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions
member.summary: Specifies the options for how members are displayed in the description of a symbol.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.None
member.summary: Includes only the name of the member.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.IncludeType
member.summary: Includes the (return) type of the method/field/property/event.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.IncludeModifiers
member.summary: Includes the modifiers of the member. For example, "static readonly" in C# or "Shared ReadOnly" in Visual Basic.
member.remarks: Accessibility modifiers are controlled separately by .

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.IncludeAccessibility
member.summary: Includes the accessibility modifiers of the member. For example, "public" in C# or "Public" in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.IncludeExplicitInterface
member.summary: Includes the name of corresponding interface on members that explicitly implement interface members. For example, "IFoo.Bar { get; }".
member.remarks: This option has no effect in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.IncludeParameters
member.summary: Includes the parameters of methods and properties/indexers.
member.remarks: See for finer-grained settings.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.IncludeContainingType
member.summary: Includes the name of the type containing the member.
member.remarks: The format of the containing type is determined by .

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMemberOptions.IncludeConstantValue
member.summary: Includes the value of the member if is a constant.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions
member.summary: Specifies miscellaneous options about the format of symbol descriptions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions.None
member.summary: Specifies that no miscellaneous options should be applied.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions.UseSpecialTypes
member.summary: Uses keywords for predefined types. For example, "int" instead of "System.Int32" in C# or "Integer" instead of "System.Integer" in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions.EscapeKeywordIdentifiers
member.summary: Escapes identifiers that are also keywords. For example, "@true" instead of "true" in C# or "[True]" instead of "True" in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions.UseAsterisksInMultiDimensionalArrays
member.summary: Displays asterisks between commas in multi-dimensional arrays. For example, "int[][*,*]" instead of "int[][,]" in C# or "Integer()(*,*)" instead of "Integer()(*,*) in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions.UseErrorTypeSymbolName
member.summary: Displays "?" for erroneous types that lack names (perhaps due to faulty metadata).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions.RemoveAttributeSuffix
member.summary: Displays attributes names without the "Attribute" suffix, if possible.
member.remarks: Has no effect outside and only applies if the context location is one where an attribute ca be referenced without the suffix.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayMiscellaneousOptions.ExpandNullable
member.summary: Displays as a normal generic type, rather than with the special question mark syntax.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions
member.summary: Specifies how parameters are displayed in the description of a (member, property/indexer, or delegate) symbol.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.None
member.summary: Omits parameters from symbol descriptions.
member.remarks: If this option is combined with , then only the parentheses will be shown (e.g. M()).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.IncludeExtensionThis
member.summary: Includes the this keyword before the first parameter of an extension method in C#.
member.remarks: This option has no effect in Visual Basic.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.IncludeParamsRefOut
member.summary: Includes the params, ref, out, ByRef, ByVal keywords before parameters.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.IncludeType
member.summary: Includes parameter types in symbol descriptions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.IncludeName
member.summary: Includes parameter names in symbol descriptions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.IncludeDefaultValue
member.summary: Includes parameter default values in symbol descriptions.
member.remarks: Ignored if is not set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayParameterOptions.IncludeOptionalBrackets
member.summary: Includes square brackets around optional parameters.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPart
member.summary: A single element of a symbol description. For example, a keyword, a punctuation character or a class name.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPart.Kind
member.summary: Gets the kind of this display part.

member.name: P:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPart.Symbol
member.summary: Gets the symbol associated with this display part, if there is one. For example, the associated with a class name.

member.summary: Construct a non-formattable (i.e. with a fixed string value).

An optional associated symbol.
The fixed string value of the part.

member.name: M:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPart.ToString
member.summary: Returns the string value of this symbol display part.

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind
member.summary: Specifies the kinds of a piece of classified text (SymbolDisplayPart).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.AliasName
member.summary: The name of an alias.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.AssemblyName
member.summary: The name of an assembly.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.ClassName
member.summary: The name of a class.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.DelegateName
member.summary: The name of a delegate.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.EnumName
member.summary: The name of an enum.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.ErrorTypeName
member.summary: The name of an error type.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.EventName
member.summary: The name of an event.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.FieldName
member.summary: The name of a field.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.InterfaceName
member.summary: The name of an interface.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.Keyword
member.summary: A language keyword.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.LabelName
member.summary: The name of a label.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.LineBreak
member.summary: A line-break (i.e. whitespace).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.NumericLiteral
member.summary: A numeric literal.
member.remarks: Typically for the default values of parameters and the constant values of fields.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.StringLiteral
member.summary: A string literal.
member.remarks: Typically for the default values of parameters and the constant values of fields.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.LocalName
member.summary: The name of a local.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.MethodName
member.summary: The name of a method.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.ModuleName
member.summary: The name of a module.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.NamespaceName
member.summary: The name of a namespace.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.Operator
member.summary: The symbol of an operator (e.g. "+").

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.ParameterName
member.summary: The name of a parameter.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.PropertyName
member.summary: The name of a property.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.Punctuation
member.summary: A punctuation character (e.g. "(", ".", ",") other than an .

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.Space
member.summary: A single space character.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.StructName
member.summary: The name of a struct (structure in Visual Basic).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.AnonymousTypeIndicator
member.summary: A keyword-like part for anonymous types (not actually a keyword).

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.Text
member.summary: An unclassified part.
member.remarks: Never returned - only set in user-constructed parts.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.TypeParameterName
member.summary: The name of a type parameter.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPartKind.RangeVariableName
member.summary: The name of a query range variable..

member.name: T:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPropertyStyle
member.summary: Specifies the options for how properties are displayed in symbol descriptions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.SymbolDisplayPropertyStyle.NameOnly
