member.summary: The type of the elements of this array.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cci.IArrayTypeReference.IsVector
member.summary: This type of array is a single dimensional array with zero lower bound for index values.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cci.IArrayTypeReference.LowerBounds
member.summary: A possibly empty list of lower bounds for dimension indices. When not explicitly specified, a lower bound defaults to zero. The first lower bound in the list corresponds to the first dimension. Dimensions cannot be skipped.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cci.IArrayTypeReference.Rank
member.summary: The number of array dimensions.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cci.IArrayTypeReference.Sizes
member.summary: A possible empty list of upper bounds for dimension indices. The first upper bound in the list corresponds to the first dimension. Dimensions cannot be skipped. An unspecified upper bound means that instances of this type can have an arbitrary upper bound for that dimension.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Cci.ICustomModifier
member.summary: Modifies the set of allowed values for a type, or the semantics of operations allowed on those values. Custom modifiers are not associated directly with types, but rather with typed storage locations for values.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cci.ICustomModifier.IsOptional
member.summary: If true, a language may use the modified storage location without being aware of the meaning of the modification.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cci.ICustomModifier.GetModifier(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Emit.EmitContext)
member.summary: A type used as a tag that indicates which type of modification applies to the storage location.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Cci.IParameterTypeInformation
member.summary: Information that describes a method or property parameter, but does not include all the information in a IParameterDefinition.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cci.IParameterTypeInformation.CustomModifiers
member.summary: The list of custom modifiers, if any, associated with the parameter. Evaluate this property only if IsModified is true.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cci.IParameterTypeInformation.IsByReference
member.summary: True if the parameter is passed by reference (using a managed pointer).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cci.IParameterTypeInformation.HasByRefBeforeCustomModifiers
member.summary: The CLI spec says that custom modifiers must precede the ByRef type code in the encoding of a parameter. Unfortunately, the managed C++ compiler emits them in the reverse order. In order to avoid breaking interop scenarios, we need to support such signatures. When this flag is set, we need to reverse the emit order.
member.remarks: We support before (correct) and after (incorrect, but works), but not in between.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Cci.IParameterTypeInformation.GetType(Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Emit.EmitContext)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cci.ISpecializedNestedTypeReference.UnspecializedVersion
member.summary: A reference to the nested type that has been specialized to obtain this nested type reference. When the containing type is an instance of type which is itself a specialized member (i.e. it is a nested type of a generic type instance), then the unspecialized member refers to a member from the unspecialized containing type. (I.e. the unspecialized member always corresponds to a definition that is not obtained via specialization.)

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cci.ITypeDefinition.IsWindowsRuntimeImport
member.summary: True if the type is a Windows runtime type.
member.remarks: A type can me marked as a Windows runtime type in source by applying the WindowsRuntimeImportAttribute. WindowsRuntimeImportAttribute is a pseudo custom attribute defined as an internal class in System.Runtime.InteropServices.WindowsRuntime namespace. This is needed to mark Windows runtime types which are redefined in mscorlib.dll and System.Runtime.WindowsRuntime.dll. These two assemblies are special as they implement the CLR's support for WinRT.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cci.IAssembly.Flags
member.summary: A set of bits and bit ranges representing properties of the assembly. The value of can be set from source code via the AssemblyFlags assembly custom attribute. The interpretation of the property depends on the target platform.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Cci.IAssembly.PublicKey
member.summary: The public part of the key used to encrypt the SHA1 hash over the persisted form of this assembly. Empty or null if not specified. This value is used by the loader to decrypt an encrypted hash value stored in the assembly, which it then compares with a freshly computed hash value in order to verify the integrity of the assembly.

member.summary: Returns zero or more strings used in the module. If the module is produced by reading in a CLR PE file, then this will be the contents of the user string heap. If the module is produced some other way, the method may return an empty enumeration or an enumeration that is a subset of the strings actually used in the module. The main purpose of this method is to provide a way to control the order of strings in a prefix of the user string heap when writing out a module as a PE file.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Utilities.FileNameUtilities
member.summary: Implements a few file name utilities that are needed by the compiler. In general the compiler is not supposed to understand the format of the paths. In rare cases it needs to check if a string is a valid file name or change the extension (embedded resources, netmodules, output name). The APIs are intentionally limited to cover just these rare cases. Do not add more APIs.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.FileNameUtilities.IsFileName(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the string represents an unqualified file name. The name may contain any characters but directory and volume separators.
member.param: Path.
member.returns: True if is a simple file name, false if it is null or includes a directory specification.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.FileNameUtilities.IndexOfExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the offset in where the dot that starts an extension is, or -1 if the path doesn't have an extension.
member.remarks: Returns 0 for path ".foo". Returns -1 for path "foo.".

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.FileNameUtilities.GetExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Returns an extension of the specified path string.
member.remarks: The same functionality as but doesn't throw an exception if there are invalid characters in the path.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.FileNameUtilities.RemoveExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Removes extension from path.
member.remarks: Returns "foo" for path "foo.". Returns "foo.." for path "foo...".

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.FileNameUtilities.ChangeExtension(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Returns path with the extenion changed to .
member.returns:
Equivalent of
If is null, returns null. If path does not end with an extension, the new extension is appended to the path. If extension is null, equivalent to .

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.FileNameUtilities.IndexOfFileName(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the position in given path where the file name starts.
member.returns: -1 if path is null.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.FileNameUtilities.GetFileName(System.String)
member.summary: Get file name from path.
member.remarks: Unlike doesn't check for invalid path characters.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Utilities.ObjectPool`1
member.summary:
Generic implementation of object pooling pattern with predefined pool size limit. The main purpose is that limited number of frequently used objects can be kept in the pool for further recycling.
Notes: 1) it is not the goal to keep all returned objects. Pool is not meant for storage. If there is no space in the pool, extra returned objects will be dropped.
2) it is implied that if object was obtained from a pool, the caller will return it back in a relatively short time. Keeping checked out objects for long durations is ok, but reduces usefulness of pooling. Just new up your own.
Not returning objects to the pool in not detrimental to the pool's work, but is a bad practice. Rationale: If there is no intent for reusing the object, do not use pool - just use "new".

member.name: T:Roslyn.Utilities.ObjectPool`1.Factory
member.remarks: Not using because this file is linked into the (debugger) Formatter, which does not have that type (since it compiles against .NET 2.0).

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.ObjectPool`1.Allocate
member.summary: Produces an instance.
member.remarks: Search strategy is a simple linear probing which is chosen for it cache-friendliness. Note that Free will try to store recycled objects close to the start thus statistically reducing how far we will typically search.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.ObjectPool`1.Free(`0)
member.summary: Returns objects to the pool.
member.remarks: Search strategy is a simple linear probing which is chosen for it cache-friendliness. Note that Free will try to store recycled objects close to the start thus statistically reducing how far we will typically search in Allocate.

member.name: M:Roslyn.Utilities.ObjectPool`1.ForgetTrackedObject(`0,`0)
member.summary:
Removes an object from leak tracking.
This is called when an object is returned to the pool. It may also be explicitly called if an object allocated from the pool is intentionally not being returned to the pool. This can be of use with pooled arrays if the consumer wants to return a larger array to the pool than was originally allocated.

member.name: T:Roslyn.Utilities.OneOrMany`1
member.summary: Represents a single item or many items.
member.remarks: Used when a collection usually contains a single item but sometimes might contain multiple.
